blocks.text: Exact Differential Equations. An exact differential equation is one that can be integrated if it is set equal to zero; thus, the expression $Pdx + Qdy = 0$ being an exact differential. The term exact differential must first be explained.
Let $P = P(x,y)$ and $Q = Q(x,y)$ be such that the derivatives being paired, or to use the more familiar notation, $\frac{\partial P}{\partial y} = \frac{\partial Q}{\partial x}$.
To solve such an equation proceeds as follows: It is sufficient to integrate $Pdx$ as though there is no term in $Q$ that depends on $y$, and put the sum of the results equal to a constant.

blocks.description: Differential equation representing the relationship between $P$ and $Q$.

blocks.text: This can also be expressed as:

blocks.latex: du = P dx + Q dy = \frac{\partial u}{\partial x} dx + \frac{\partial u}{\partial y} dy.
blocks.description: An expression showing the relationship of the function $u$ with respect to $x$ and $y$.

blocks.text: and this is exactly the same as the original equation.

blocks.description: Condition for an exact differential equation.
